text: Read the whole thread. It's a recollection & a generalization--that I acknowledge--in that it surely doesn't apply to most parents. I don't think it's possible to describe a cultural memory succinctly in a single tweet. But I do think this is a topic worth thinking about.

text: (4/4) This wasn't all parents, or even most (I'd assume). But there was a prevailing attitude by parents & teachers that if boys were polite, got good grades, played sports, etc. that they were good boys, future success stories. Inherently innocent. I wonder if that's changed.
author: ahauslohner

text: (3/4) In which parents taught their kids how to get straight A's, excel at extracurriculars & get into top notch universities. They'd reward them w cars for the 16th bday & an unspoken license to drink on wknds (their kids were responsible), but didn't teach them not to rape.

text: Lawyers say a far more typical case is Mr. Al-Shawbi, feat. in tday’s story. He’s a US citizen too, & his teen son is stuck abroad. But unlike the high-profile cases, Shawbi couldn’t afford 2 hire a lawyer, & there r no powerful ppl lobbying on his behalf

text: As for the doctor, he was fortunate & savvy enough 2 enlist his congressman. Rep. French Hill (R-Ark.)’s spokeswoman later told me Hill called the US embassy many, many times. If it wasn’t for Hill’s efforts, the doctor’s wife *would NEVER have gotten a visa,* she said. (4/4)
author: ahauslohner

text: But there’s a noticeable pattern in the handful of cases that have actually gotten visas in the end. Neither the girl nor the doctor’s wife r “typical” cases: the girl was featured in news stories & briefs 2 the Supreme Court, & a Justice even asked abt her during a hearing (3/4)
author: ahauslohner

text: After this story came out, the young girl with cerebral palsy was granted a waiver to come to the US. Then, recently, Mohamed Al-Awadhi, the doctor in my story, received word that his wife, who suffers from a heart condition, would also get a waiver. (2/4)
author: ahauslohner

text: Then, last week, @Slate reported on two US consular officials who described the internal guidelines they’ve received at US embassies abroad, instructing them to avoid* issuing waivers. One of them called the waiver process “a sham.”
author: ahauslohner

text: The Center for Constitutional Rights did an even deeper dive into the system through which certain needy cases from the banned countries are supposed to be able to get visas, despite the ban. CCR focused on Yemenis. You can read what the found here:
author: ahauslohner

text: The administration says it provides visa waivers to certain people (like spouses, kids, the sick, etc) from the banned countries so they can still come to the US. Last month, I took a close look at that system & found that’s not actually true.
author: ahauslohner

text: Talked to an American dad in North Carolina. He was trying to console his 16-yr-old son earlier over the phone, but didn't know what to say. The boy is Yemeni, stuck now in Djibouti, &was hoping to come live with dad in US. Now he's begging his dad not to send him back to Yemen
author: ahauslohner

text: I spoke to a university professor, whose research into new ways of diagnosing cancer &other illnesses is being funded by NIH & the state of North Dakota, among others. His wife & son are Americans. But he's Iranian &has been unable to get a green card. Now they're going to leave.
author: ahauslohner

text: Tday I talked to an American engineer who just last yr was on the verge of buying a house in the burbs, waiting fr the arrival of his wife and 3 young daughters. Now he's on the phone, unable to console his wife. She and the kids are Yemeni nationals, stuck in a war-torn capital.

author: ahauslohner

text: (3/4) Collectively, they were only able to identify around 25 people who had actually gotten waivers to come to the US in spite of the ban. The stories of rejection—of parents separated from children, husbands frm wives, sick ppl frm caregivers—were far more numerous.

text: (2/4) I called up more than 30 of the biggest immigration legal and advocacy groups, as well as individual attorneys working with large numbers of clients impacted by the ban. I asked them to give me the names of other attorneys handling cases, and then I called them too.
